instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a water damage has green light but doesn't turn on. I started measuring around and i'm missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> so i watched on one of louis videos with similar problem so when this signal took me to the PCH i checked for the voltage that powers the PSH  -- <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> and that took me to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, and there i have voltage on pin 8 (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_CSPWRGD</SIGNAL>) and pin 2 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>) and the important signal im missing is pin 1 (<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>) so i tried to find where this signal comes from and that took me <CHIP>U8160</CHIP> and that component doesn't exist on the board just empty pads. This shit is confusing. Any ideas ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Basics first. PPBUS? 3v3 on L7560? Where was the liquid?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> was missing and that took me to <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and from the Enable signals <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> was missing the other 2 enable signals were present and the chip was getting power, so this took me to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
and that signal was missing. That signal comes from the PCH and after based on Louis videos i was following the signal that powers the PCH

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Water damage affected area was from <CHIP>U5870</CHIP> all the way across the opposite  side

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is giving a pulse when connecting power. I hope you are using a REAL 85W charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I don't have any pulse it's 0 v. I always use original charger and yes its 85W

threads.message: All of them on pin one they have 3.3v and <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> pin 3 is 3.3 v, <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> pin 2 is 3.01V and <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> pin 2 is 3.29
